prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Line widths in the targeted sources are known to be around 5 km/s. In order to spectrally resolve these lines a spectral resolution of ~1 km/s is desired; at the same time, a large bandwidth is needed to observe many lines simultaneously so no finer velocity resolution can be used. With spectral averaging of 2 to limit the data rate to close to 12 Mb/s, the spectral resolution is set to the reasonable number ~1.3 km/s.

Studied hot cores are on the order of 1.5" in size. Potential structures like outflows are of similar sizes. With a largest angular scale of 3.0" these structures within range. The spatial resolution of 0.5" is small enough to image the hot cores and other structures in the stronger lines.

The methylamine (CH3NH2) abundance is estimated from methylamine/methanol ratios found in the galactic center source Sgr B2 and multiplied with column densities of methanol in known high mass hot cores. This results in a column density of ~4x10^15 cm^-2. With this density emission fluxes are calculated for methylamine for sources of ~1.5" size and transitions of 6 km/s line width. Peak fluxes of 11 mJy are calculated for CH3NH2. Therefore a RMS of 2 mJy is needed to ensure a 5 sigma detection of methylamine at its expected abundances.

Because of the large number of lines targeted in a wide bandwidth a high data rate of 12.21 MB/s is reached. Because spectral lines in the sources have a bandwidth of ~5 km/s a spectral resolution of around 1 km/s is desired. Spectral averaging of 2 sets this number to ~1.3 km/s, which is still reasonable. However, larger spectral averaging settings result in velocity resolutions of >2.4 km/s, which is insufficient to resolve the transition lines. Therefore, this slightly higher data rate is needed.
Line widths in the targeted sources are known to be around 5 km/s.

Studied hot cores are on the order of 1.5" in size. Potential structures like outflows are of similar sizes. With a largest angular scale of 3.0" these structures within rang. The spatial resolution of 0.5" is small enough to image the hot cores and other structures.

Methylamine has low line fluxes due to it large partition function. At the small synthesized beamsize of 0.5" it becomes harder to detect. Therefore a RMS of 2 mJy is needed to ensure a 5 sigma detection of methylamine at its expected abundances.

Because of the large number of lines targeted of a wide bandwidth a high data rate of 12.21 MB/s is reached. Because spectral lines in the sources have a bandwidth of ~5 km/s a spectral resolution of around 1 km/s is desired. Spectral averaging of 2 sets this number to ~1.3 km/s, which is still reasonable. However, larger spectral averaging settings result in spectral resolutions of >2.4 km/s, which is insufficient to resolve the transition lines. Therefore, this high data rate needed.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to make the first detection of methylamine (CH3NH2) outside the galactic center source Sgr B2 and to obtain the first spatially resolved studies of amine-containing molecules methylamine and formamide (NH2CHO) and their potential parent species in a number of high mass hot cores. Both CH3NH2 and NH2CHO can be linked to the creation of amino acids, peptide bonds and ultimately the formation of life. Despite their importance to prebiotic chemistry, the formation pathways of both species are unknown. Several mechanisms have been proposed and studied in laboratory environments, including hydrogenation and UV induced radical-radical chemistry. To test these mechanisms, five chemically rich high-mass hot cores will be targeted in CH3NH2, CH2NH, NH2CHO, and HNCO, together with CH3OH as a reference for abundances. Spatially resolved data will put constraints on the different formation pathways, both through spatial correlations within one source and through similar abundance ratios between sources.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Graduate School of Science and Faculty of Science, Kobe University
